intro: Salaxis imbricata, commonly known as the mountain thimble, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of South America. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family, which includes many plants with milky sap and showy flowers. The plant is characterized by its slender, branched stems and clusters of small, tubular flowers that are typically pink or white. Its leaves are opposite and elliptical, often with a slightly hairy texture. Salaxis imbricata is adapted to grow in rocky or well-drained soils at high altitudes.
